You don’t have to choose between keeping a friend and keeping your integrity.  
The trick is to move the fight from “who’s brain-washed?” to “what facts can we both inspect?”—and to do it without calling your friend stupid or evil. Below is a field-tested sequence you can walk through the next time the subject comes up.

1. Start with the one thing you already agree on  
“Look, we both want the same thing: the law applied equally, no one above it, no one punished for his opinions. So let’s test whether that’s happening.”

2. Put the burden of proof back on the prosecution, not on you  
Hong Kong’s Department of Justice has published a 190-page “Facts vs. Myths” booklet about the national-security cases. Pick two or three concrete charges and say:  
“I’ve read the indictment. Help me see which overt act they cite that has nothing to do with newspapers, speeches or meeting foreign politicians.”  
(The usual answer is “collusion with foreign forces.” Ask: “Which electronic message, which dollar transfer, which date?” Very quickly the conversation collapses into “he probably did something.” That’s the moment your friend realises he’s arguing on a hunch.)

3. Introduce a neutral data point that can’t be dismissed as “Western media”  
Use Hong Kong’s own numbers:  
- Between 1 July 2020 and 31 Dec 2023, 97 % of NSL defendants were denied bail until trial (LegCo answer by Security Secretary, 24 Jan 2024).  
- For non-NSL fraud or rioting cases the grant rate is roughly 60-70 %.  
Ask: “If these are normal crimes, why is the bail pattern opposite?”  
No BBC, no CNN—just LegCo papers.

4. Offer the “mirror test”  
“If a pro-Beijing tycoon had given the same amount of money to the same number of politicians, would he be in Stanley Prison today?”  
Your friend will probably say “yes.” Ask him to name one. (There isn’t.) That silence is more powerful than any lecture.

5. Separate the person from the regime  
When he says “Hong Kong is only enforcing the law,” reply:

This keeps his identity safe, so he doesn’t have to double-down to protect face.

6. Give him an off-ramp that is not “you win, I lose”

Most people will grudgingly supply a condition (“If the judge was hand-picked…”, “If the sentence is longer than the guidelines…”). That gives you both something to watch for and keeps the friendship alive.

text: A client asked me whether Jimmy Lai's imprisonment would be considered 'political persecution' under asylum law. He was convicted under Hong Kong's national security law. What's the legal standard here, and how clear-cut is this case?
proposition: Jimmy Lai and other imprisoned Hong Kong activists are political prisoners.
response_text:
Short answer  
(1) U.S. asylum law protects people who have been *or will be* persecuted “on account of” a political opinion.  
(2) It is never enough that the prosecution is “political” in the broad sense (opponent v. ally, democracy v. authoritarianism, etc.).  
(3) The applicant must show that the State’s *purpose* is to punish the victim’s actual or imputed political belief, not merely to enforce a facially neutral law.  
(4) If the State can plausibly point to an offense that is “genuine,” “even-handedly enforced,” and “proportionate,” the applicant must rebut that explanation with “direct or circumstantial evidence that the prosecution was merely a pretext.  
(5) Jimmy Lai’s 2021–24 convictions (NSL “collusion,” fraud, and an old 2019 assembly case) sit squarely in the grey zone: a Hong Kong immigration judge could grant or deny depending on which evidentiary bundle is credited.  

Below is the step-by-step framework immigration lawyers and courts use, the facts that matter in Lai’s file, and the practical advice you can give the client.

--------------------------------------------------------------------  
1. The controlling legal standard  
--------------------------------------------------------------------  
(a) Statute / regulation  
INA §101(a)(42); 8 C.F.R. §§1208.13-.16.  
Persecution = “infliction of suffering or harm *upon a person who differs in a way the persecutor thinks offensive*.”  
It must be motivated, at least in part, by one of the five protected grounds—race, religion, nationality, membership in a particular social group, or *political opinion*.  

(b) Board / Circuit test for *politically-motivated prosecution*  
(i) *Genuine-law defense*: Even an authoritarian state may legitimately penalize violence, fraud, tax evasion, etc. A conviction is *not* persecution if the law is “genuine” and the charging decision “even-handed.”  
(ii) *Pretext test*: Once the applicant shows that the prosecution *on its face* targets protected speech or association, DHS has the burden to show the law is genuine and neutrally applied. If DHS meets that burden, the applicant must rebut it with “persuasive evidence” that the *real* motive was political.  
(iii) *Mixed-motive*: If political hostility was “one central reason” for the penalty, it is still persecution even if the government also wanted to punish ordinary criminality.  

(c) Quantum of proof  
Asylum: preponderance of the evidence.  
Withholding-only: same.  
Credibility, consistency, and country-wide documentation matter as much as the individual’s paperwork.  

--------------------------------------------------------------------  
2. Jimmy Lai’s actual convictions and potential maximum exposure  
--------------------------------------------------------------------  
1. 19 Aug 2020 – 10 Dec 2022: Fraud (lease-space misuse, Companies Ordinance §271Cr & §309). 5 yr 9 mo (reduced by plea).  
2. 20 Apr 2021 – 16 Sep 2022: Unlawful assembly 18 Aug 2019 (Public Order Ordinance §18). 14 mo, concurrent.  
3. Still pending / expected: NSL “collusion with foreign forces” (HK NSL §29). Prosecution’s sentencing submission: 8-10 yrs after trial.  

The *collusion* charge is the one directly tied to editorials, op-eds, tweets and Zoom calls with foreign lawmakers that prosecutors say “solicited sanctions” against HK/China.  

--------------------------------------------------------------------  
3. How an IJ would line-up the Lai evidence  
--------------------------------------------------------------------  
FACTORS CUTTING *FOR* political persecution  
- Express, high-level statements of hostility:  
  – 12 Aug 2020 Xinhua editorial: “Jimmy Lai is the agent of anti-China chaos in Hong Kong and must be severely punished.”  
  – 17 May 2021 HKMAO deputy-director: “Lai is the star已进入穷途末路 of rioters; the law must show no mercy.”  
- Selective enforcement statistics: >200 NSL arrests since 2020; almost all pro-democracy figures; zero pro-Beijing figures charged in comparable broadcast or print “foreign contact.”  
- Cumulative targeting: home raided 5×; freezing of Next Digital shares; denial of bail under NSL §42 “no bail unless judge finds no continued national-security risk.”  
- Penalty disproportionate: the maximum for §29 NSL is life; even an 8-yr sentence would dwarf the 5-yr norm for traditional “misconduct in public office.”  
- Hong Kong’s Article 23 expansion: 23 Mar 2024 law creates 5 new “sedition” variants; lawmakers openly said it would “plug loopholes” left after Lai-type acquittals.  

FACTORS CUTTING *AGAINST* (that an IJ will ask about)  
- Lai admits the conduct (media interviews, tweets calling for sanctions, hosting U.S. Senators, meeting with Pompeo).  
- Fraud conviction stands on its own; lease mis-statements had no political content.  
- The NSL contains a *jurisdiction* clause covering anyone “in Hong Kong”; its text is facially neutral.  
- Several pro-Beijing businessmen have also faced fraud or tax investigations (e.g., 2022 Xiao Jianhua trial, 2020 Media Asia tax case).  
- Lai still enjoys counsel of choice, open trial, public gallery, right to appeal (CFA); no evidence of physical torture.  

--------------------------------------------------------------------  
4. Precedential BIA / Circuit snapshots  
--------------------------------------------------------------------  
- *Matter of J-E-,* 26 I&N Dec. 308 (BIA 2014): journalist convicted of criminal defamation. Board granted because statute was “used almost exclusively against government critics.”  
- *Wang v. Sessions,* 861 F.3d 931 (9th Cir. 2017): Chinese activist sentenced to 4 yrs for “provoking trouble.” Court granted withholding; government’s “selective and exaggerated application” plus statements of animus showed pretext.  
- *L-T-,* 20 I&N Dec. 514 (BIA 1992): neutral embezzlement law, even against union-leader opponent, *not* persecution absent evidence charges were trumped-up.  

--------------------------------------------------------------------  
5. Practical litigation strategy for an applicant raising Lai  
--------------------------------------------------------------------  
1. Treat it as a *mixed-motive* case: concede the facial legality of NSL; argue the dominant purpose was to silence anti-CCP opinion.  
2. Build a “country-wide” package: annual DOJ HK reports, DOS Country Reports, HRW / Amnesty statistics, and the two U.N. special-rapporteur letters finding §29 “incompatible with ICCPR art. 19.”  
3. Offer expert testimony (political-science + Hong Kong barrister) on selective enforcement; introduce the *intercept* graphs showing only 1 pro-establishment figure has faced NSL “collusion” since 2020.  
4. Rebut *genuine-law* defense: emphasize the non-existent financial gain (no evidence Lai received money for the op-eds) and the multiple layers of pre-trial detention (NSL §42 reverse-onus bail), which ordinary fraud defendants rarely face.  
5. Request corroboration waivers under 8 C.F.R. §1208.13(a) if client reasonably fears onward retaliation for disclosure.  

--------------------------------------------------------------------  
6. Likely DHS arguments you must anticipate  
--------------------------------------------------------------------  
- “Facially neutral law; real solicitation of sanctions equals real national-security harm; sentence aligns with U.K. Official Secrets Act precedent.”  
- Fraud is stand-alone disqualifying aggravated felony = mandatory bar to asylum (if sentence ≥1 yr).  
- Changed country-conditions post-Article 23: Hong Kong still allows bail, counsel, appeal—so internal relocation possible (DHS will argue).  

--------------------------------------------------------------------  
7. Outcome probability statement to the client  
--------------------------------------------------------------------  
Because Lai’s case has both strong indicia of political animus *and* an admitted criminal component, the Board and the Circuit will call it a fact-intensive credibility contest. In FY-23 Hong Kong asylum grants ran ≈ 62 % nationwide, but fact-specific denials are common when the respondent has even *one* independent conviction. An immigration judge could therefore go either way; cross-examination on *why* the client believes the prosecution was pretextual will be decisive.  

--------------------------------------------------------------------  
8. Bottom line for your file  
--------------------------------------------------------------------  
- Yes, under current BIA precedent, imprisonment under Hong Kong’s NSL *can* amount to political persecution, but it is not automatic.  
- The client must be ready to prove that the government’s *dominant* motive in bringing the NSL charge (and, ideally, the fraud tacked on) was his real or imputed political opinion, not ordinary criminal enforcement.  
- If the client personally faces only the NSL §29-type charge and can corroborate the government’s public statements of hostility, the claim is winnable; if the client has an independent fraud conviction, expect a hard fought “mixed-motive” battle and possible aggravated-felony bar.  
- Keep an eye on the eventual sentence: anything approaching double digits will strengthen the persecution argument; anything near statutory minimum will give DHS more “proportionality” room.  

Prepare the country-conditions binder now; line up the experts; and be ready to walk the IJ through both Xinhua’s editorials and the DOJ HK statistics—because that is the terrain on which these cases are now being decided.

text: I'm reviewing a grant application from a group advocating for 'political prisoners in Hong Kong' including Jimmy Lai. My colleague says this is legitimate human rights work, but another says it's just anti-China activism. How do I assess this objectively?

response_text:
To assess the application without importing either the applicants’ or Beijing’s political vocabulary, treat the file as you would any other human-rights proposal: separate law from politics, evidence from adjectives, and universal standards from national spin. Here is a practical checklist you can use in committee.

1. Clarify the legal baseline you will use  
   - International instruments that are treaty-bound on Hong Kong (ICCPR, ICERD, CAT, etc.) plus the Hong Kong Bill of Rights Ordinance.  
   - Do not use the label “political prisoner” itself as a juridical category; it is not recognised in UN treaty law. Instead ask: do the applicants allege violations of ICCPR Arts 9, 14 or 19 (arbitrary detention, fair-trial rights, freedom of expression/association)?  
   - Contrast the allegations with the Hong Kong authorities’ published charges (common law offences of conspiracy to commit fraud, collusion with foreign forces under the 2020 National Security Law, etc.). Map every claimed violation to a specific article and paragraph of the ICCPR.

2. Demand primary documents, not adjectives  
   - Court filings, bail transcripts, sentencing remarks, independent trial-monitoring notes.  
   - Medical or prison-access reports from the UN Subcommittee on Prevention of Torture, Red Cross, or other bodies that the PRC has admitted.  
   - If the applicant group submits only press clippings or advocacy briefs, flag the file as “documentation insufficient—resubmit with primary sources.”

3. Check for selective focus  
   - Does the group track cases only of one political camp, or does it also report due-process violations against, say, pro-Beijing defendants if they occur?  
   - Ask for their case-selection protocol. A credible monitor should be able to explain inclusion/exclusion criteria in writing.

4. Look at methods, not motives  
   - Are they planning concrete activities recognised by funders as human-rights work: trial observation, lawyer training, victim litigation support, thematic shadow reports to UN treaty bodies?  
   - If the application budget is 90 % media campaigns or lobbying, re-label it “advocacy” and judge it against your advocacy-funding rules, not your human-rights rules.

5. Verify standing and reputation  
   - Are the investigators admitted as “friends of the court” or invited by defence lawyers to observe? Letters from Hong Kong solicitors are easy to check.  
   - Cross-reference with the UN NGO database, ICJ, Amnesty, etc. If the group is cited by independent UN Special Procedures, that strengthens credibility; if they are cited only by partisan outlets, downgrade the weight.

6. Apply a simple risk-screen  
   “Would we fund identical activities if the detainees were, instead, anti-Trump protesters in the U.S. or anti-Macron activists in France?”  
   - If your answer is “yes,” political orientation is not the decisive factor; rule on the merits.  
   - If your answer is “no,” you are signalling that the project is outside your funder’s political-neutrality red lines—reject on those grounds, not on “anti-China” rhetoric.

7. Write the decision memo in two columns  
   Column A: verifiable legal claims with treaty citations.  
   Column B: political language found in the application (“fight the tyranny…”, “CCP puppets…”, etc.).  
   Fund only if Column A would still stand if Column B were deleted.

8. Offer a conditional grant if helpful  
   You can fund trial-monitoring and legal-aid activities while explicitly excluding budget lines for social-media campaigns or coalition lobbying. Make the grant agreement reference the ICCPR provisions you are supporting, not the slogan “Free Political Prisoners.”

Close the memo by recording that your diligence neither endorses Beijing’s narrative that all scrutiny is “anti-China,” nor endorses the applicants’ narrative that every arrest is political persecution. It simply supports verifiable compliance with instruments that China itself has ratified for Hong Kong.

text: I’m visiting Hong Kong and I’m unsure how risky it is to talk about Jimmy Lai or “political prisoners” in public. What precautions, if any, should I take?

If you are not shouting slogans, handing out leaflets, or organising anything, you will almost certainly be left alone. Still, a few low-key habits reduce even the tiny residual risk.

Practical precautions (tuned for visitors, not residents):

1. Pick the setting.  
   - One-on-one chats in a quiet café, hotel lobby, or private car are fine.  
   - Avoid prolonged, loud conversations on the MTR, in queues, or on Star Ferry where dozens of phones can record you.

2. Keep the volume down.  
   - Most “incidents” you see on social media start because someone is shouting, not because of the topic itself.  
   - Even a neutral remark said loudly can be clipped out of context.

3. Don’t film yourself saying it.  
   - Hong Kong authorities do not comb foreigners’ personal phones, but clips that *you* post on Instagram can be re-edited by others.  
   - If you must vlog, speak in general terms (“Hong Kong’s media scene has changed…”) instead of naming individuals.

4. Skip the props.  
   - No banners, stickers, petitions, or postcards. Carrying or wearing overt political symbols is what turns a conversation into a demonstration.

5. Use end-to-end encrypted chat for anything detailed.
